CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Margaret Ethel Jameson (later SJ) was born at Whitby in North Yorkshire.

P.BIRTHPOSITION: She was the eldest of her parents' four children—three daughters and a son.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her familial and spiritual attachments to Yorkshire were intense and resilient. She writes in her autobiography, Journey from the North, that the span of my life is even longer than it seems, since its roots are twisted round hundreds of lives passed in the same place.15
Born into the English middle class, with a father who had made good without an education, SJ often felt gauche and provincial in the company of her confidently upper-middle-class friends.

SJ's mother, Hannah Margaret (Gallilee) Jameson, was the dominant influence 361 on her early life. Hannah was the eldest of seven children born to George Gallilee and his first wife. She did not get on with his second wife. Hannah is said to have instilled ambition and discipline in her own children by thrashing them frequently. In her autobiography, ST writes of Hannah's feelings of boredom and entrapment as a young mother at home, her bitter marriage, and of her own desire to please her mother. The two women had a close and sometimes tense relationship. 18, 24, 32, 351 When writing about Hannah's death in about February 1937, her daughter observes, [h]er life did not end then; it goes on echoing through mine, and will echo there until it and I are both silenced. 355

The author's father, William Storm Jameson, was a sea captain. His mother was George Gallilee's second wife by a previous marriage, though SJ asserts that the couple kept their families apart, and further that [m]y mother cannot have had even the most short-lived sense that she was marrying a stepbrother. 24 After having little success in school (he may have been dyslexic), William was sent out as apprentice on a ship at the age of thirteen: SJ pointed to this as a central element in the formation of his harsh character. She was never close to her father. 34-5
SJ and her three siblings were born between 1891 and 1906.33 In her autobiography she writes most frequently and vividly of her younger sister Dorothy Jameson Pateman and her brother, Harold Jameson.

When Margaret (later SJ) was a very small girl she and her mother often joined her father on sea voyages to various European ports. She notes in Journey from the North that [t]he first thing I remember is the deck of a ship in sunlight,17 though she later cautions her reader, [d]o not believe that the earliest memories are anything but disguised choices.28-9 Her childhood home (on land) that she recalled most distinctly was 5 Park Terrace in the sea-going town of Whitby.28
SJ taught herself to read, probably driven to it by boredom.29

At about the age of eight she was sent to a boarding school run by the Misses Corney. She drily calls the rote memorization taught at the so-called school . . . the best in the world, since it leaves the child's imagination severely alone.29

SJ later attended a private school run by Lily Ingham, then spent a year at Scarborough Municipal School. She began writing the Cambridge exams at the age of thirteen and went to Scarborough to prepare for the last of them. With strong encouragement from her mother she secured her future university plans by becoming the first young woman awarded one of only three County Scholarships in the North Riding of Yorkshire. i

While at Leeds University, SJ served as Secretary of the Women's Representative Council of the Student Union, met her future husband Charles Douglas Clarke (also a student), and wrote an undergraduate thesis on Blake. She recalled that at this point she had a strong desire for an academic career, but was too undisciplined to hope to realize it.51-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ was the first woman awarded a BA in English Language and Literature from Leeds University. She graduated with first class honours.

SHORTPROSE.P: After completing her undergraduate degree at Leeds she won, the same year, a John Ruteau Fellowship. It was intended for study at University College, London, but she soon transferred to King's College.36: 7055, 58, 64

While at King's, SJ accepted an invitation to join the Eikonoklasts, a group of men that met for weekly discussion in a campus common room. Jameson recalled with relish that they were skeptics, unavowed anarchists, self-dedicated to the unmasking of hypocrites, politicians, clericals, reactionaries, bigots, and dogmatists of all ages and conditions. . . . We admired certain people—[A. R.] Orage, H. G. Wells, Freud, the writer of La révolte des anges [Anatole France]—so sincerely and blindly that we adopted their enemies.65-6
For about a year Jameson was also a volunteer tutor at a working women's college in Earl's Court, founded by Mary Jane Bridges-Adams.67

SJ first planned to write her graduate thesis on representations of pantheism in French and German literature. Following consultation with W. P. Ker at University College, she changed it to a study of modern European drama.68-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ received her MA in English after working at King's College, University of London; at this date the London MA was a final degree, equivalent to a doctorate elsewhere.

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ's thesis was also approved by Leeds University, which had supported her work with a research award. It was published as Modern Drama in Europe, 1922.i

While completing her graduate work SJ lived (with her mother's permission) with three close friends, all of them male. She was pleased with her decision not to live with girls or women, but with young men who [w]ithin reason . . . treated me like a younger brother, with as much unconcern and good-temper. 71 These friends were the brothers Sydney and Oswald Harland, and Archie White. 63-4 Another friend, Charles Douglas Clarke, visited only occasionally and elicited dislike and disappoval from Jameson's room-mates. 72

They lived first in rooms on Herne Hill, then in Shepherd's Bush. SJ developed a lasting passion for London along with these friendships. She expresses throughout her autobiography deep regret for the loss of the vibrancy and freedom of this pre-war period.passim

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ married Charles Douglas Clarke. They had first met as students at Leeds University.

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ is vague about the details of her wedding in Journey from the North. She there refers to Clarke, who was a schoolmaster of American extraction and may have been working as a journalist, only as K. At some point after marrying, the couple moved to another room in Shepherd's Bush, this time in Caxton Street. The room was tidy but possessed an ingrained squalor and the musty smell of poverty.75

In late 1913 SJ attempted suicide by overdosing on phenacetin pills. In Journey she writes of the tensions between herself and her husband, as well as their poverty and her feelings of despair and a reckless wish to be anywhere but where I was.74 After taking the pills, Jameson became frightened and confessed to Clarke, who threatened to call the police but brought her a doctor instead.

P.SEPARATION: The couple separated for the first time, temporarily, in January 1914, when SJ returned to Whitby.76

SHORTPROSE.P: In about April 1914, after some time in Whitby, SJ was reunited with her husband in Kettering, a town in the Midlands where he had taken a job as a schoolmaster. Jameson detested the town and they rented a room in a small hotel instead of securing a house of their own. She later stated without jest that her hatred of a settled domestic life was, is, an instinct, and borders on mania. 82

In Kettering SJ found respite from a place she disliked in walking and in a subscription to the Times Book Club, which brought to her attention J. A. Symonds's Renaissance in Italy and Allen Upward's The Divine Mystery. She also began writing her first novel, which remained unpublished.81-5

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ delivered her son, Charles William Storm Clarke, at her mother's home in Whitby.

SHORTPROSE.P: The baby, called Bill, was her only child. Describing the moments just following his birth, Jameson wrote that [r]estless as I was, my life had its fixed centre.96

Jameson had at least one more pregnancy, which she ended with a self-induced miscarriage. I remember sharply what I did, but I am not going to tell: I don't want either to harm some other young woman, as desperate as I was, who may read this book, or to pass for insane.94

After Kettering, Jameson and her small family lived in Liverpool, where Clarke had taken another posting. When he enlisted in the wartime forces Jameson and their son became camp-followers for some time, at first in Reading.98, 105-10
Critic Margaret B. McDowell calls the marriage ill-considered and violent,36: 72 and notes that the couple lived emotionally and physically apart for most of it.

As critic Joanna Labon observes, SJ defined herself by war and lived much of her life in angry opposition to it.34 Though Jameson undertook most of her activism during the 1930s and 1940s, her political development was well under way by the beginning of World War I. She supported the Fellowship of Reconciliationklh: link to event #907? and self-identified publicly as a pacifist for many years after this. However, she records in her autobiography feeling a lack of respect and sympathy for at least one of the first pacifists she met, another Liverpool schoolmaster.88-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ's younger brother, Harold Jameson, was killed while serving with the Royal Flying Corps.

SHORTPROSE.P: By November 1918 SJ and her son were living again at Hannah Jameson's home in Whitby. They were, not very unhappily, without Clarke, who remained in the army and sent his wife occasional, minor financial support. After an unsuccessful attempt at persuading him to apply for an advertising job in London, Jameson decided to enquire about the position herself. 131-3

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ was a copywriter with the Carlton Agency, a London advertising firm.

SHORTPROSE.P: She chose to build a career of her own not only because her husband was an unreliable, to her undesirable, partner and father, but also because of her feelings of ambition, boredom, and restlessness.135 Her starting wage at the agency was four pounds per week.

She spent half of her earned income on Bill's boarding at the home of a Miss Geeson, who ran a morning school in the village of Ruswarp near Whitby. Despite her desire for an active public life, SJ loathed leaving her son in another's care and in later years deeply regretted her decision to be away from him.135-41, 149-53
For some of this early London period she lived in a shared flat in St John's Wood.

She shared this flat with Elizabeth and John Gleeson. Elizabeth was the sister of writer Stephen Graham, and John was a former Eikonoklast. Storm had a close friendship with Elizabeth, but not with John.135-41, 149-53

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ was the sub-editor of the New Commonwealth journal, a job which overlapped with her shorter period of copywriting work.

SHORTPROSE.P: The journal, formerly called the Christian Commonwealth, had just been purchased by F. Thoresby, who intended to make it a weekly vehicle for his various socio-political views. Jameson described him as a theosophist who also held an honest business man's vision of a society run on the lines of a good firm, reasonably generous to its workers.154 She found these interests and ideals odd but harmless.154

Thoresby recruited Jameson after admiring her first published novel, The Pot Boils (1919). As sub-editor she earned fifty pounds a month: for this, her responsibilities included creating the journal's layout as well as contributing articles, essays, and reviews. One of several turning points in her approach to her creative and social responsibilities occurred when she encountered another journal's dismissive coverage of severely impoverished children in Germany and Austria. She recalled that [f]or the first time in my life I had the sense, horribly familiar later, of a dark wave of pain, cruelty, [and] fear, gathering force at the other side of Europe and about to rush down.156 Initially she responded to this by ensuring that news of post-war destitution in Europe received regular, prominent treatment in the New Commonwealth.

Her husband was demobilized in 1920 and he and SJ again lived together in London. When he was unable to find work Jameson gave up her job, urged Thoresby to hire her husband in her place, and spent some time in Whitby before returning to London.166-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ spent some weeks as a researcher for Margaret Sanger. She prepared data on English sexual health for the English edition of one of Sanger's books (either What Every Girl Should Know or The New Motherhood).

SHORTPROSE.P: In her description of this work Jameson neither explains how she came to be employed by Sanger nor offers her own perspective on Sanger's career. However she calls Sanger a generous woman: 172 the two had agreed that Jameson would be paid fifty pounds for her research, but when it took longer than expected Sanger paid her twice as much.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ worked as a publishing representative for Alfred A. Knopf in London.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was introduced to Alfred and Blanche Knopf by her publisher and friend Michael Sadleir.188 In her autobiography she comments, I wrote to every well-known author under the age of fifty. I had a few civil phrases on the end of my pen . . . my profound admiration for your work . . . should you, at any time, consider changing your publisher in America, I beg that you will give me the chance to . . . your reputation, your etc, etc . . . .195

SJ moved in various creative circles as she began to write, review, and undertake other literary work. She first met Dora Marsden in 1913: Marsden was editor of the Egoist and Jameson wrote a number of dramatic reviews for the journal at this time. She commented that I was not much given to respect in my first youth, but I knew enough to revere pure intellect when I met it.77 She provided Marsden with much-needed emotional and practical support during the 1920s.165-7 As a young woman she also became friendly with Harriet Shaw Weaver.9077-8

Michael Sadleir first took Jameson to the Thursday evening salons hosted by Naomi Royde-Smith at her Queen's Gate home. These gatherings were attended by Rose Macaulay, Arnold Bennett, Edward Marsh, and Frank Swinnerton. Jameson remained in contact with Macaulay for many years, and left a vivid and appealing description of her appearance and demeanour when entertaining her guests.160-1 Several weeks after Jameson's first visit, Royde-Smith teasingly told her that Rose calls you a most likeable child. I doubt whether you're either likeable or a child, in spite of your voice.162

SJ greatly admired Walter de la Mare and they began to correspond in 1921, shortly before she published an essay on him in the English Review. She made several visits to his home at 14 Thornsett Road, South London and to his later home near Taplow.164-6

Jameson met Romer Wilson, Charles Morgan, and J. W. N. Sullivan through her Knopf connections. By about 1924 she and Edith Sitwell had visited each other's homes. Jameson felt that in spite of my respect for her as a poet, some resistance towards an aristocratic insolence she neverthless fell into whenever she or her brothers were attacked by a plebeian critic.201 Jameson attended parties held by J. D. Beresford; she met John Middleton Murry at one of Beresford's parties and they wrote to each other several times in 1923. One letter from Murry told Jameson that Katherine Mansfield had been very much pleased by Jameson's review of one of her short stories. Mansfield also sent the message that she could offer some financial support (twenty pounds) to Jameson if necessary. SJ observed Violet Hunt and May Sinclair at other gatherings. Amabel Williams-Ellis, Noel Streatfeild, Stanley Unwin, and Richard Hughes began friendships with Jameson during this early period. Jameson was also a friend of both Naomi Mitchison and Q. D. Leavis (undeterred by Leavis's quite sharp criticism of Mitchison as a writer), and of R. H. Tawney, possibly from a later period than this.192-20555 Leavis, a woman with few friends of her own sex and few outside the world of Cambridge, deeply valued her epistolary friendship with Jameson.

CHRONPROSE.DIVORCE: After years of animosity and separation, SJ divorced Charles Douglas Clarke and assumed custody of their son.

SHORTPROSE.P: Though the reunion of Jameson and her son was not permanent, they moved to Weybridge at some point in 1924. She began work on her fifth novel, as her Knopf salary did not cover their cost of living.208-10
She also continued her love affair with ex-soldier Guy Patterson Chapman, her future second husband, with whom she had become involved while they were both married to others.208-10

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ was co-manager of Alfred A. Knopf's London branch with Guy Patterson Chapman (who became her husband on 1 February 1926).

SHORTPROSE.P: By the time the couple met, Chapman was running his own publishing firm (Chapman and Dodd, later Guy Chapman).103-13 When Knopf bought out the company and retained Chapman and Jameson, it was agreed that Jameson would work part-time and at half of Chapman's salary. However, she wrote that [i]n the event I worked five full days in the office.234

She was once charged by Knopf with the task of attempting to persuade Wyndham Lewis to keep them as his American publisher, which she did on a cold, rainy day as vile as his temper.236 She called the friendship that she and Chapman enjoyed with Edward Thompson the one pure gain from our two and a half years' servitude with Knopf.237

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ married Guy Patterson Chapman, who in time became a respected author and historical scholar.

SHORTPROSE.P: While he studied at the London School of Economics, Jameson supported their household, sometimes taking on more commercial work rather than devoting herself to further intellectual experiment. In their biography of Vera Brittain, Paul Berry and Mark Bostridge comment that Vera was not the only friend over the years to wonder at [Jameson's] apparent willingness to eclipse herself for Chapman's sake.361 SJ called her relationship with Chapman a happy difficult second marriage.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ wrote to Vera Brittain, thereby initiating a close (but not permanent) friendship.

SHORTPROSE.P: Their friendship was sparked by their shared investment in the question of how women may effectively balance career and family demands. Both published on this topic, and while Jameson was discussing it in a series of Evening Standard articles she visited Brittain, then pregnant, at her Nevern Place flat. When they first met in person Brittain was surprised by Jameson's youth: she had expected someone older because at this time Jameson was better known than herself.360 They also continued discussions by letter. Jameson wrote to Brittain on 8 October 1927: I suppose that by good management and by keeping enough of one's head and heart out of the career, one can manage a husband and even the most exacting of careers. I loathe domesticity myself and I couldn't even contemplate marriage as a career. But add a baby to the affair, and . . . something has to go, either the career or the child. . . . You see, it's neither as easy as my smug articles in the Evening Standard pretend, nor so simple as the Time and Tiders imagine.211, 304

The two women were friends through the 1930s and their relationship became increasingly intimate after the death of Winifred Holtby on 29 September 1935. Brittain stayed with Jameson and Chapman the night after Holtby died; Jameson supported Brittain at Holtby's funeral; Brittain once wrote that Jameson was the closest friend she had after Holtby's death. Brittain was also supportive of Jameson, offering her financial aid when she needed it and persuading George Brett to sign SJ on at Macmillan after she quarrelled with her American editor. Just before leaving for an American lecture tour in January 1940, Brittain appointed Jameson guardian to her children. (Henry Andrews, Rebecca West's husband, was another guardian.)359-62, 390211 Catherine Clay gives a chapter to this friendship in British Women Writers, 1914-1945: professional work and friendship, 2006.

DIV2.HEADING: The Well of Loneliness and Anti-Censorship

SHORTPROSE.P: In November 1928 SJ was one of many authors (including E. M. Forster, Virginia and Leonard Woolf, and Desmond MacCarthy) prepared to testify in defence of Radclyffe Hall's lesbian novel The Well of Loneliness, then being tried on obscenity charges.228 It is possible that Jameson became involved in the case through her friend Vera Brittain, another ready witness and one of Hall's most outspoken, lasting supporters.

Remembering her university years, SJ called herself and the other Eikonoklasts socialists of a sort,65 though they disliked Fabianism for its apparent bureaucracy. Jameson was an active member of the Labour Party by 1931, when she attended its conference at Scarborough. In 1933 she attended the Labour conference in Hastings as Whitby's first delegate. She was sometimes assumed to be, but never was, a Communist.65, 270, 321
SJ travelled frequently throughout her life, in both personal and professional capacities.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ spent several weeks in Berlin, where she witnessed events leading up to Germany's presidential elections.

SHORTPROSE.P: Here Jameson observed, with local contacts, the nation's impoverished, violent, politically-uncertain climate. She deepened her friendship with Lilo Linke, a young woman she had first met at the Labour Party Conference held in Scarborough in late 1931. In Berlin, Linke wrote for the Deutsche Volkswirt (which she described as the Berlin equivalent of the Economist),272 was an active Social Democrat, and lived in a small flat near the Kurfürstendamm boarding house where Jameson stayed. Jameson later wrote an introduction to her book Tale Without End.47 Again as a viewer rather than a participant, Jameson attended a memorial service for First World War dead by the Stalhelm (a dull declamatory meeting)267 and a Communist rally at the Sportpalast (Why this passion for a Messiah, shared by both extremes?).277
The year 1932 was a key point in the development of SJ's socio-political consciousness: she stated that she began to construct [her]self as a writer-activist at this time.301

Jameson described the 1933 Labour Conference at Hastings as haunted by the ghost of German Social Democracy, in the shape usually of a young doctor or lawyer, with a pale intelligent face, and no money. What did these revenants hope from their assembled English comrades?321 Jameson began to associate with refugees in London from about this year forward. Though she later undertook more formal, concerted refugee work with PEN, she now hosted some of the first exiles from Hitler's Germany.321-5

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ and Philip Noel-Baker co-ordinated a dinner hosted by Viscount Cecil at the Wellington Club, in order to marshal well-known authors against war.

SHORTPROSE.P: Guests included Rebecca West and Rose Macaulay. This event led to the publication of the anthology Challenge to Death: A Symposium on War and Peace (1934)

SJ claims in Journey from the North that [t]here is no literary society in London, in the meaning of the words: groups form and dissolve, like the tiny circular ripple an insect makes on the surface of a stagnant pond, nothing more serious.314 During the 1930s and the war years most of her friends were leftist politicians, journalists, historians, and economists. In the early 1930s she began the habit of record[ing] many thousands of spoken words291—transcribing each day's conversations on often intermingled personal, creative, and political issues. She later destroyed these papers.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ and her husband, Guy Patterson Chapman, spent about five weeks in Spain, staying in a village north of Barcelona.

SHORTPROSE.P: In 1935 SJ's thoughts were turning even more sharply toward the fearful certainty of another war: in her autobiography she describes her awareness of this certainty flicker[ing] continuously, just below the horizon, a lightning flash, a sudden thinning out of the clouds, another flash, another.333 After listening to US journalist Dorothy Thompson describe the Night of the Long Knives (Hitler's purge of the SA, announced on 13 July 1934), Jameson became interested in the apparent compulsion of a dictator, once in power, to destroy his earliest supporters. She chose to write about this in a novel, which became In the Second Year, planned in Spain and begun in Norway in June.334-5

In Authors Take Sides on the Spanish Civil War, Louis Aragon notes that Jameson signed statements supporting Spain's Republican government in 1936 and 1937. Jameson's possible connections to Aragon and the Republican movement are not yet clear.39, 45
Still a pacifist between the wars, SJ signed the Peace Pledge Union in May 1936.link to event #920? 40354

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ became president of the English Centre of PEN International. She held this position through the Second World War, until 1945.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: The international body had first met in New York on 13 May 1924, when it was addressed by the founder of the original, English organization, the writer Catharine Amy Dawson Scott.

SHORTPROSE.P: In Journey from the North Jameson calls her acceptance of this position one of my more insane blunders425 but notes that she could not refuse it, either when it was first offered or later during the war, because of her horror at the psychological and social state of Eastern European refugees. Nothing in me is fiercer, more obsessive, more nearly involuntary, than my loathing of the cruelty that issued in Auschwitz, except the sense that exile is only the human condition pushed to its furthest limit.344

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ began an extended tour of Prague, Vienna, and Budapest in her capacity as president of the English Centre of PEN International.

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ found the Munich Agreement of September 1938 especially repugnant after observing the last struggles for safety and independence in these cities. She did not adopt a militaristic or pro-war stance: in fact, she remained staunchly anti-war. However, the consequences of failed appeasement strongly influenced her shift away from pacifism. She expressed her intense disapproval of the Agreement partly by resigning from the Peace Pledge Union, though its letterhead and its journal Peace News continued to list her as a sponsor for some time.41403

SJ's work on behalf of the imprisoned and the exiled required her to spend an immense amount of time and energy in diverse literary, social, and political circles. Joanna Labon asserts that [u]nder Jameson's direction, PEN became the headquarters for an intellectual campaign fought with military efficiency and astonishing stamina.41 Often functioning on less than three hours of sleep per night, SJ petitioned institutions in Britain and elsewhere to rescue authors, scholars, and others persecuted under Fascism. Jameson raised money to help them, she applied and pushed for visas, and when they got to England she fed them, housed them, and washed up after them.41 She took this on with Hermon Ould (a poet and secretary of PEN International), while E. M. Forster, H. G. Wells, and many others provided vital contributions to the effort.425-34
SJ continued to write (novels, pamphlets, essays) and accept other public commitments during the war.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ began a brief volunteer stint with the Ministry of Labour, organizing correspondence stored in its Special Register.
The Home Office appointed the English Centre of PEN to report on the status of refugee writers who had been or could be interned. SJ and Hermon Ould undertook the bulk of this advisory work.

SHORTPROSE.P: In her autobiography Jameson also briefly mentions compiling a report on women in munitions factories for the Ministry of Supply at this time. She spoke on the BBC at least once, in a radio address to the New York branch of PEN on 3 July 1941.507
Not only were SJ's books banned at an early point in Hitler's regime; she was also named in the Gestapo's Black Book of about 1940 for her anti-Nazi activities before and during the war.36: 72

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: With World War II looming, SJ and her sister Dorothy Pateman began to share Heathfield, a large house at Mortimer in Berkshire, with their husbands and Dorothy's children.

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ did not remain solely at Heathfield throughout the war. Like Vera Brittain, she took rooms in London in Portland Place: while Brittain wote England's Hour (published in 1941 and dedicated to Jameson), the two women often toured the bombed city together. Chapman re-enlisted in January 1941 and when he was posted to North Wales, Jameson moved with him. She stayed very near Portmeirion, the community designed by Clough Williams-Ellis.501-4, 537-840-1

At Portmeirion SJ enjoyed the friendship of both Williams-Ellises, Clough and his wife Amabel (née Strachey). She later wrote warmly of her affection for Amabel, though she said that in the early stages of their acquaintance her elegance, unconscious air of authority, quick racing mind, a little intimidated a badly-dressed young woman whose gauche provincialism she either did not notice or gaily ignored.538

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ invited Vera Brittain live with her and her sister's family at Heathfield, the house they had taken at Mortimer in Berkshire. Brittain accepted, and stayed about ten weeks.

SHORTPROSE.P: Brittain's stay was strained by the tense relations between her and Jameson's family, with Jameson often caught in the middle of their arguments. Brittain sent Jameson a letter of gratitude for her efforts in December of that year. After that, however, their friendship was threatened by other pressures. First they quarrelled over Jameson's characterizations in The Hour of Prague, and then the writing and publication of her pamphlet The End of This War, 1941, prompted an increasingly hostile series of letters between them. Jameson had only recently begun to disclose to Brittain her sharp turn away from pacifism, and in her pamphlet she used an excerpt of one of Brittain's letters to illustrate the weaknesses of the pacifist position. Brittain removed Jameson from her will and, on discovering this, Jameson effectively ended their relationship: though she had refused any financial legacy, she had warmly accepted her appointment as Brittain's literary executor and guardian of her children. Brittain attempted a reconciliation in early 1942, but the break proved permanent.395-6, 405, 409, 413-18

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ's youngest sister, Dorothy Pateman, was killed by a German bomb that hit the People's Pantry at Reading, where Pateman had been working with the Women's Voluntary Service (WVS).

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ was at work on a novel when her husband delivered the news that her sister had been killed. She later remembered, I actually finished the sentence I had been writing when he came in: like the body of a decapitated hen, my brain went on twitching for several minutes.541 While Storm focusses mainly on her mother's devastation when dealing with her brother's death in her autobiography; when writing of Dorothy's death she details her own long-lasting grief.

SJ remained highly politically engaged as World War II ended. After stepping down as President of PEN's English Centre, she sat on the executive board of PEN International.36: 72 She protested against the bombing of Hiroshima in a letter to the Manchester Guardian. In her autobiography, as well as several times expressing her intense horror at the threat of nuclear war, she also comments that this threat provides an ironic, perhaps delirious outlet for psychological and creative release. Many people are competent to tell us what to do to survive. Only the artist—a class of persons which includes the man who set a pot of geraniums outside his hovel in the ruins of Warsaw—can tell us how, in what conditions, men can survive as human beings. . . . I had a feeling of exhilaration, even gaiety. Now that none of us is safe, we can really laugh, really mock our pedantic teachers, really live.551

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ and three other British citizens travelled to Warsaw and Cracow, sponsored by the Polish Embassy in London, to witness conditions in war-ravaged Poland. In November Jameson visited Prague for the same purpose.

SHORTPROSE.P: In Poland SJ delivered messages from exiles in London, met the Vice-Foreign Minister and the Minister of Culture (as well as surviving poets, musicians, young scholars, and others), and toured such institutions as the National Museum, now laid waste. In Cracow she watched documentary films on Auschwitz and Majdanek created by Polish filmmakers. In either Cracow or Warsaw she saw photographs, taken by German soldiers themselves, of Nazi street executions, sexual assualt, and other acts of violence.555-81

In Prague, Jameson spent time with her longtime friend Jiřina Tůmová and various politicians and bureaucrats, including Edvard Benes or Beněs. Beněs was the former president of Czechoslovakia whom Jameson came to know at the time of her first trip to that country. She wrote that I felt for him an affection . . . I never felt for any other public figure. He had the failings and weakness of a man of reason who believes that reason ought to prevail.446 She also went to Pankrác Prison, where Tůmová had been jailed for some time and where instruments of torture and murder, such as a guillotine, were concealed from the Red Cross. After this Jameson toured Modeřany and Hagibor internment camps, where German men, women, and children were held before trial, further imprisonment, and/or deportation.583-9, 595 The last area Jameson saw at Hagibor was a hospital room reserved for dying infants. Jameson records her perception of it in her autobiography. I bent over one of the cots: the tiny face dissolved and for less than a breath I saw through its soft skull the guillotine in Pankrác, the walls of the little bathroom, the terror of a boy the instant before he is killed, the decent bodies of women heaped, naked as maggots, in Terézin and Auschwitz—the spume of agony flowing back and forth across Europe. Then I saw only the dying baby.602

SJ used her observations from these trips in various articles and at least one radio broadcast, which she made from Warsaw at the end of her stay in Poland. It is unclear what organization she broadcast through or to whom she addressed her talk.579-80

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Harrison Salisbury, Moscow correspondent for the New York Times, told SJ that she was listed in the Soviet Book of Death.

SHORTPROSE.P: This hit-list contained the names of all those monsters and cannibals who openly preach destruction of millions of human lives and the greatest values of world culture.662 In her autobiography Jameson claims that she was delighted662 rather than alarmed by this news, as she was included on the list along with André Malraux, whose writing she respected greatly.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ was a delegate to the UNESCO Congress of the Arts in Venice.

DIV2.HEADING: Later Work and Travel in England and Abroad

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ moved from southern England to Leeds: her husband Guy Patterson Chapman had been appointed to a Chair of Modern History at Leeds University, where Jameson herself had studied.

SHORTPROSE.P: She and her husband lived in a hotel for years at Leeds (as Jameson had done during her early married life), so that she did not have to undertake the burden of domesticity.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ and her husband Guy Patterson Chapman left England for the United States to spend a year at the University of Pittsburgh.

SHORTPROSE.P: At Pittsburgh Chapman lectured on history while Jameson taught creative writing. She also accepted another teaching appointment at a nearby women's college (mentioned briefly and unnamed in her autobiography). Her work week consisted of twenty-two hours of tutoring, plus evaluating her students' projects. She did not enjoy these responsibilities, believing not only that creativity cannot be taught but also that writing ought not to be undertaken as one's sole profession.631-3
Jameson and Chapman travelled extensively within America, visiting New York City, Kansas City, and the states of Connecticut, Vermont, Massachusetts, Ohio, and Texas.622-56

They were back in the United States from September to December 1957, when Chapman accepted a position at Princeton's Institute for Advanced Studies. In later years they travelled to Italy, Greece, and France. Jameson felt a strong passion for the latter and visited it many times.261, 405, 683, 746, 749-51, 773, 791
The couple made their last home in Cambridge.47

In Ohio they met novelist Louis Bromfield, who was also hosting Blanche and Alfred Knopf. While in Dallas Jameson lunched at the Dallas News building and was seated opposite Dorothy Parker, as terrible as an army with banners, in a Tyrolean hat.650 On their second American visit they began a friendship with scholars Zara and George Steiner.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ's husband, historian Guy Patterson Chapman, died in Cambridge, where they had already lived for some time.

SHORTPROSE.P: SJ filled her life with family concerns, activism, travel, and friendships with diverse women and men. Her extensive literary output, sometimes inspired by her own rich experience, frequently examines women's changing domestic and public roles. Though she felt some of the consequences of limitations placed upon women in her historical moment, she was not stopped by them: instead, she often assumed her linked personal, social, and creative commitments in a position of leadership. Late in life, however, she denied any formal identification with feminism. At the age of ninety-one, an interview with Janet Watts which was published in the Observer Magazine on 5 September 1982, she claimed that she had never thought of myself as either male or female. You just got on with what you had to do.42, 47 One recent critic provides an alternative interpretation: that Jameson's feminism is so profound that she takes it for granted.8: 82

SJ shaped her personal perspectives and career turns with her finances in mind, but never placed primary importance on accumulating or retaining wealth. She spent some of her early years in poverty and, once published, continued with her creative writing while she took on a variety of commercial assignments in order to support herself and her family. She preferred to spend any income she had on herself and loved ones or to give it to those in greater need, rather than build up any savings. One of her longtime friends, author and former suffragist I. A. R. Wylie, asked Jameson shortly before her own death how much she had set aside for retirement, and was sincerely horrified when Jameson admitted: Not a penny.94

SJ's demanding work, travel, and personal commitments exacted a serious toll on her health. She contracted diphtheria as a young woman, probably when she nursed her son through it. Frequently exhausted, she also had precondition angina and an ulcer during the years leading up to and through the Second World War.192, 500, 529 In April 1955 she underwent surgery for an unnamed ailment. Because she had every intention of dying like Emily Brontë, in [her] chair,716 Jameson agreed to only a few days in hospital. However, her operation and recovery were marred by complications and she remained hospitalized for eight weeks. She commented that at this point I and my body were entirely separate.685

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: SJ died in Cambridge at the age of ninety-five; late in her life she had developed Alzheimer's disease.

SHORTPROSE.P: This trouble had not been apparent in her interview of 1982.
